meaning: The regulation of the internal conditions of a cell or organism to maintain optimum conditions for function in response to internal and external changes.
A type of cell that detects stimuli
A change in the external or internal environment
Receives and processes information from the receptors
A muscle or a gland that brings about responses which restore optimum levels
A system that enables humans to react to their surroundings and coordinate their behaviour
The part of the nervous system made up of the brain and the spinal cord which coordinates the response of effectors
Cells which transmit information between one another as electrical impulses
The nerve pathway that follows a reflex action. Includes structures such as sensory/relay/motor neurones and synapses.
An automatic and rapid action that doesn't involve the conscious part of the brain.
An organ made up of billions of interconnected neurones, with several regions that carry out different functions.
The part of the brain responsible for involuntary functions such as breathing.
The part of the brain responsible for posture and coordination
The part of the brain responsible for high-level functions including emotions, thoughts, personality etc
A sensory organ containing light and colour sensitive receptors
The process by which the eye adjusts to focus on near or far objects
The processes by which the eye adjusts to dim or bright light
Also known as short-sightedness - a condition where light is focused in front of the retina. Treated with a concave lens.
Also known as long-sightedness - a condition where light is focused behind the retina. Treated with a convex lens.
The area of the brain containing receptors sensitive to blood temperature and triggers mechanisms accordingly.
The process where blood vessels expand to allow heat to escape through the epidermis
The process where blood vessels shrink to prevent heat from escaping through the epidermis
A fluid produced at the sweat glands, which evaporates, taking thermal energy with it. This lowers body temperature.
Where skeletal muscles contract and relax very quickly, to release energy as heat.
The system made up of glands that secrete hormones into the bloodstream. It is slower than the nervous system but its effects last longer.
A chemical secreted by a gland with a target organ where it produces an effect.
The master gland, found in the brain, which secretes hormones into the blood that trigger the release of other hormones.
A hormone produced by the pancreas causing glucose to leave the blood
A substance made of lots of connected glucose molecules stored in the liver and muscles.
A disorder in which the pancreas fails to produce sufficient insulin
A disorder in which the body cells no longer respond to insulin produced by the pancreas
A waste product converted from ammonia for safe excretion
A hormone responsible for controlling water levels, released when blood becomes too concentrated
A treatment for kidney disease where blood is removed, filtered, and returned to the body
A treatment for kidney disease where a kidney is implanted into the patient's body from an organ donor.
The main female reproductive hormone, produced in the ovary.
The release of eggs every 28 days.
The main male reproductive hormone, produced by the testes.
A hormone causing the maturation of an egg in the ovary
A hormone that stimulates the release of the egg
A hormone involved in maintaining the uterus lining, as well as oestrogen.
The prevention of pregnanacy - can be done by hormonal or non-hormonal methods.
A hormonal method of contraception containing hormones that inhibit FSH production.
Injection, implant, skin patch and oral contraceptives are examples of this.
IUDs, spermicide, abstinence, sterilisation and barrier methods are examples of this.
Methods that prevent sperm from reaching the egg, such as condoms and diaphragms.
A procedure involving giving a mother FSH and LH to stimulate the maturation of several eggs, which are fertilised in a laboratory.
A hormone that stimulates the basal metabolic rate, playing an important role in growth and development.
A hormone produced in times of fear or stress which prepares the body for 'fight or flight'.
A response to the stimulus of light in plants, causing them to grow towards it.
A family of plant hormones that control cell elongation
A response in plants to the stimulus of gravity
